thread.title: Hundreds gather to mourn Ore. shooting victims
thread.title_full: Hundreds gather to mourn Ore. shooting victims

author: Tracy Loew, (Salem, Ore.) Statesman Journal
title: Hundreds gather to mourn Ore. shooting victims
text:
ROSEBURG, Ore. — Hundreds of people gathered at Roseburg’s Stewart Park Thursday night for a candlelight vigil in honor of those killed and wounded in a mass shooting at Umpqua Community College earlier in the day. “Today is not about the shooter,” Douglas County Commissioner Chris Boice told the crowd, urging them not to say his name.
The official program lasted only 15 minutes, but people milled around for more than an hour afterward, talking, hugging and crying.
Many people at the service said they knew of families who had not yet heard from their students. Names of those killed have not been released. Douglas County Sheriff John Hanlin said Thursday night it would be at least Friday before identities would be made public.
"Obviously, notifications of the families is our priority, and we would ask that media respect the victims and their families as they manage these most difficult hours," Hanlin said.
USA TODAY
Ten killed in shooting at Ore. community college
USA TODAY
Sheriff in Oregon mass shooting probe opposes gun control
USA TODAY
Andy Parker: Oregon shooting shows we are at war
UCC student Brittany Eggers, 18, said she was a couple of buildings away from the shootings.
Narci Quintara, an Umpqua Community College student, holds a candle during a vigil at Stewart Park in Roseburg, Ore., on Thursday, Oct. 1, 2015. Students, families and supporters gathered after a shooter killed 10 at Umpqua Community College. (Photo: Anna Reed, (Salem, Ore.) Statesman Journal)
She learned about it when her mother called her in class. Shortly after that, she said, the building was locked down.
Students were searched twice, then allowed onto buses to be driven to the Douglas County fairgrounds to reunite with family, she said.
Eggers said she was overwhelmed by attendance at the vigil. Although she grew up in the city, she said, “I didn’t really know how tight a bond Roseburg has.”
Umpqua Community College President Dr. Rita Cavin speaks during a vigil at Stewart Park in Roseburg, Ore., on Thursday, Oct. 1, 2015. (Photo: Anna Reed, (Salem, Ore.) Statesman Journal)
